data.title: Britney Spears lists Sarah Jessica Parker among women who inspire her
data.meta_description: Sarah Jessica Parker was 'touched' to be included in Britney Spears' list of women she looks up to.
data.text:
Britney Spears has shared a sweet tribute to the women who have inspired her over the years, and Sarah Jessica Parker was moved to be one of them.

The singer, 39, took to Twitter and Instagram to share the list, writing: ‘These are the women that have truly inspired my life!!!!

‘Being away from family & my boyfriend while quarantining was really hard for me but the good thing about social media is we can connect in a different way!!! These cool ladies always add a spark to my day!!!!’

Among them were Sharon Stone, Natalie Portman, Sarah, her sister Jamie Lynn Spears, Miley and Noah Cyrus and yoga teacher Tawny Janae.

SJP was humbled to be included, replying to Britney: ‘Thank you dear @britneyspears.

‘I think you know how I feel about you. For a long time. Sending all my best and touched that you included me to be companion. X, SJ’.

It comes after Britney left fans confused by posting about the colour ‘red’ on her Instagram account without any further explanation.

Fans had wondered whether they cryptic message held any clues about Britney’s conservatorship, which the Free Britney movement is fighting to get her freed from.

The Toxic star has been under conservatorship since 2008 and this week her lawyers have filed to have her father, Jamie Spears, removed from his role overseeing her financial and personal affairs.

Jamie had been in control of both her financial and personal decisions since 2008, stepping down from the latter in 2019 due to health reasons.

Care professional Jodi Montgomery had replaced him on a temporary basis, but her lawyer has filed a petition to make the role permanent as well as asking Jamie to resign from overseeing Britney’s personal life.

The papers, obtained by PA, also reserve the right for Britney to eventually request an end to the conservatorship, adding: ‘Petitioner expressly reserves the right to petition for termination of this conservatorship under Probate Code section 1861.

‘Nothing in the within petition shall be deemed to constitute a waiver of that right.’
